title: How hip-hop allowed Eminem to escape all of his childhood trauma
description:
Eminemhas an interesting backstory, and his childhood has intrigued fans for years. When the Grammy-award-winning rapper first came to prominence, his anti-establishment, offensive, and angry demeanour fascinated people. As such, his life before fame has been of much interest to the culture.
While trying to establish himself as an artist in Detroit, Eminem had a relatively conventional style of rapping, and the content of his music was nothing special, but this wasnâ€™t him. Following the disastrous rollout and egregious critical reception of his debut albumInfinite, Eminem realised he was holding back and needed a vehicle to say what he honestly thought and felt he needed an alter-ego.
Over the years, many saddening stories have come to light concerning the emceeâ€™s upbringing and life before fame, whether domestic violence, poverty or other; the culmination came to fans in the form of Slim Shady.
Although Eminem often touched on the trauma he went through living with his mother and the struggles he then had in hisdysfunctional relationship with Kim Scott.One chapter of his life he rarely speaks about is his social life, particularly in school.
Slim Shady is an arrogant, rude, brash character, but Eminem was far from this during his years in high school, and many who have chronicled his life have found he was the victim of ghastly bullying in school and frequently dealt with being beaten up by his peers â€” much of it race-based.
In a 2011 interview with Anderson Cooper for the renowned show60 Minutes, Eminem opened up about his schooling and how it was a horrific experience for him. Unveiling how his motherâ€™s drug addiction forced him into a predicament where he was living with different family members, bouncing between Michigan and Missouri, Em explained, â€œI would change schools two, three times a year, and that was probably the roughest part,â€ he said. â€œ[I got] beat up in the bathroom, beat up in the hallways, shoved in the lockers, just, for the most part, being the new kid.â€
One of Eminemâ€™s bullies attacked him so violently that it resulted in the lyricist spending ten days in a coma in the hospital after a blunt-force blow to his head. The song â€˜Brain Damageâ€™ on his sophomore album,The Slim Shady LP, referenced one of his bullies and the real-life head trauma he faced.
In a 1999 interview withRolling Stonemagazine,the â€˜Stanâ€™ rhymervividly recalled the bullyâ€™s actions, recounting, â€œ[He used to] beat the s*** out of me! I was in fourth grade, and he was in sixth. One time, he came running across the schoolyard and hit me so hard into this snowbank that I blacked out.â€
Eminemâ€™s uncle Ronnie Polkingharn introduced him to hip-hop music after playing him the 1984 Ice-T track â€˜Recklessâ€™. After this awakening, he quickly fell in love with what he heard and started absorbing the music of significant hip-hop artists like the Beastie Boys, Rakim, Masta Ace, LL Cool J, and NWA. The stories of Compton and the streets of Los Angeles enthralled him and made him forget, momentarily, about the problems he was having.
Hip-hop and its aggression gave Eminem a release for his anger and the stories told by other rappers allowed him to mentally escape from what he was dealing with at home and at school. It has long been suggested and even partially confirmed by Em that the repressed anger, humiliation and hatred he had for the world as a result of his experiences with bullies is what led to the birth of Slim Shady, but it was the genre of hip-hop that allowed him not only to escape but pushed him to express himself.

title: Which rapper is the biggest box office draw in Hollywood?
description:
To show versatility and improve their portfolios, rappers often venture outside ofhip-hop. Whether itâ€™s fashion, media production, real estate, or tech, more and more rappers are venturing outside of music to see where they can display their skill sets and make money.
One of the most common ventures for an artist outside music, especially for rappers, is acting. Acting is often considered a relative of music. When we look more closely, we see that films require scores and soundtracks to emphasise various emotions further. In reverse, music requires videos (film) to help aid the communication of the track.
The two art forms are intertwined, so it is no wonder that the first step outside of rap for MCs is film. However, acting is not simple, and music artists cannot just walk onto a set thinking that they are in for an easy ride.Acting is a complex craftthat requires hours and, for professionals, years of honing your skills until you get every emotion down to a tee. The way you walk, talk, and even breathe can change the type of feelings you evoke. There have been countless films, including rappers, with some of the most famous actually doing exceptionally well concerning box office sales.
From8 MiletoBarbershopandAbove The Rim,countless movies have featured rappers in leading roles, and some have become sensations. Still, many MCs take to acting more quickly and are more believable in their roles. While some hip-hop artists make mere cameos, others play characters with all their hearts and communicate their charactersâ€™ emotions.
Charlie Ahearnâ€™s 1983 movieWild Styleis often seen as the first feature film that embraced rap music. With appearances from the likes of Grandmaster Flash, Fab 5 Freddy, and the Cold Crush Brothers, although it didnâ€™t exactly break any box office records, it was integral in bringing hip-hop culture into the mainstream.
Since 1983, the culture has come leaps and bounds. In fact, it has progressed so much that, in 2025, we rappers have managed to transition from rapping to writing, directing, starring and even producinghigh-budget Hollywood films. Some have even pulled in over a billion dollars at the box office.
Whether itâ€™s Ice Cube, Queen Latifah, 50 Cent or LL Cool J, the sheer amount of money hip-hop artists have generated for Hollywood is staggering. However, there is one former rapper who sits on top of the rest concerning their box office draw.
As officially reported byThe Numbers,Will Smith has pulled in $9.54 billion in his acting career thus far. Whether itâ€™sBad Boys, I Am Legend, Men In Blackori, Robot,Will Smith is by far the most successful rapper-turned-actor. Soon after his explosion onto the rap scene in the late 1980s alongside DJ Jazzy Jeff as The Fresh Prince, Smith found himself on TV screens across the US.
Will Smith is primarily renowned for being an actor, but many elder figures in hip-hop also know him as a rapper. Although several of his records were overtly commercial and extremely radio-friendly, he still put out his fair share of music. From â€˜Gettinâ€™ Jiggy Wit Itâ€™ to â€˜Summertimeâ€™, Smith and his discography undoubtedly have a place in the hip-hop history books.
The $9.54 billion he has earned at the box office began withBad Boysalongside Martin Lawrence, but his career snowballed after this, and things have never been the same.

title: How many guest verses has Eminem done in his entire career?
description:
Eminemhas had what can only be described as a breathtaking journey in his career. From being homeless, working fast food jobs and battle-rapping in the grimiest parts of Detroit, the young man was quickly flung into fame and was soon a Diamond-certified artist.
Before hisSlim Shady LPrelease in late 1999, Em was a musical genius on the verge of suicide due to his extreme poverty. Em had been on the underground in Detroit for years with his first album,Infinite, performing poorly, receiving little to no airplay by DJs in his city, and as a white rapper, everybody had written him off.
Em lived in the â€˜8 Mileâ€™ area of Detroit, meaning he lived near the road that divides Detroit. The 8-mile-long M102 motorway (colloquially referred to as â€˜8 Mileâ€™) is an infamous highway that is known for effectively segregating the metropolitan area of Detroit. Detroitâ€™s inner city is rundown, and residents are primarily African-American. On the other side of the 8 Mile road, middle-class white neighbourhoods thrive. The road marks one of the steepest income divides in America.
Before his discovery by an Interscope intern at the 1997 LA Battle Rap Olympics, Em was effectively penniless. However, once his demo went into the hands of Dr Dre, things quickly changed, and within five years, he was one of the hottest MCs in the US and was appearing on tracks with the best rappers, such as Jay-Z, 50 Cent and many others.
Eminem once revealed how he approaches writing his guest verses in an interview withGenius,unveiling, â€œWhen Iâ€™m writing, Iâ€™m in the syllable game. Iâ€™m connecting five-six-seven-eight syllable phrases where every syllable rhymes. I get heavy into that. When I start rapping something, and I think of more syllables that connect with it, sometimes I want to just keep the scheme going forever.â€
Elaborating on how he has done it on more than one song, the rapper continued, â€œIâ€™ve done it before in songs, where the syllable scheme of the first verse ends up being the syllable scheme of the second verse, and the third verse â€” all the way down. I do it because the lines start connecting and making sense. Once I find something and lock in, it comes out pretty quick.â€
Eminem only features on tracks with artists that he actually enjoys and respects and wonâ€™t hop on any song. Some of his best verses are on othersâ€™ tracks and he has appeared on various singles.  The â€˜Stanâ€™ rhymer has, of course, worked with multiple Aftermath acts, including Xzibit, 50 Cent, Dr Dre, and Kendrick Lamar.
Some of his most well-known collaborations include the likes of Dr Dreâ€™s â€˜Forgot About Dreâ€™, Nicki Minajâ€™s â€˜Romanâ€™s Revengeâ€™ andJay-Zâ€™s 2001 smash â€˜Renegade.â€™ Eminem even produced the latter.However, few know the number of tracks Eminem has officially featured on.
As a featured artist on singles and tracks combined, theEncorecreator has recorded 172 guest verses. One of his most successful collaborations was with Rihanna in 2010 for â€˜Love The Way You Lie,â€™ a diamond-selling single.

title: Who is the best-selling New York rapper of all time?
description:
Many people consider New York the mecca of hip-hop, which has produced some of the biggest rappers in the genre. That competitiveness has led to people proclaiming themselves the â€˜King of New Yorkâ€˜ over the years, but when it comes to sales, only one rapper can proudly claim that title.
Business Insiderwrote a report in September 2024 that revealed the 16 rappers who have sold the most albums of all time. Much of the list was made up of rappers from New York, giving the East Coast the ultimate bragging rights.
At number seven on the list is LL Cool J with 12.5million album sales. The rapper from Long Island was one of the first to achieve mainstream success with his debut album,Radio, released in 1985. He has one number-one album to his name in 2000â€™sG.O.A.T. (Greatest of All Time), with 2002â€™s10also peaking at number two. Platinum albums in his catalogue includeBigger and Better,Walking with a Panther,Mama Said Knock You Out,Mr SmithandPhenomenon.
Next up, at number six, is Nas, also with 12.5million album sales. While he might not be the best-selling, many consider him to be one of the greatest rappers of all time, starting with his classic debut albumIllmaticin 1994. Despite the critical success of his first album,It Was Writtenremains Nasâ€™ best-selling album, topping the Billboard 200 chart in 1996. He hasplenty of number onesto his name, includingI Amâ€¦,Hip Hop Is Dead,UntitledandLife Is Good.
Stepping up the numbers a little, DMX is positioned at number five with 14 million album sales. The Yonkers rapper, who died in 2021, boasts a stellar discography, with his first three albumsItâ€™s Dark and Hell Is Hot,Flesh of My Flesh, Blood of My Bloodandâ€¦And Then There Was Xselling a combined 12million copies. Each project topped the Billboard 200, as well as his next two albums,The Great DepressionandGrand Champ.
50 Cent takes the fourth spot with 15.5million album sales. The G-Unit boss is best known for his classic 2003 albumGet Rich or Die Tryinâ€™, which debuted at number one and is nine times platinum. His second album,The Massacre, also topped the chart and is six times platinum. It continued his success with hits like â€˜Candy Shopâ€™ and â€˜Just a Lilâ€™ Bitâ€™.
At number three is Biggie Smalls with 21million album sales. The Notorious B.I.G. only released one album during his lifetime,Ready to Die, which is considered one of the best rap albums of all time. His second album,Life After Death, released 16 days after he was killed, sold 690,000 copies in its first week and debuted at number one on the Billboard 200.
The Beastie Boys are number two on the list with 23million album sales. Their debut album,Licensed to Ill, released in 1986, is one of the best-selling albums of all time and has achieved diamond status. The LP debuted at number one, along with later albumsIll Communication,Hello NastyandTo the 5 Boroughs.
Jay-Z easily takes the crown for the best-selling rapper in New York history, having sold over 33.5million albums.All 13 of his albumshave gone platinum, including his last album,4:44, which was released in 2017.
He has an incredible run of albums to reach number one on the Billboard 200, with his last 11 albums topping the chart, beginning withVol. 2â€¦ Hard Knock Lifein 1998. The likes ofVol. 3â€¦ Life and Times of S. Carter,The Blueprint,The Black AlbumandMagna Cartaâ€¦ Holy Grailare among some of his biggest albums.

title: The two rappers Mary J Blige respects the mostï¿¼
description:
For the uninitiated,Mary J Bligeis the unofficial Queen of Hip-Hop Soul. The nickname was given to her by Andre Harrell: â€œBlige was living in a housing project in Yonkers, NY when the late Andre Harrell signed her to his Uptown Records, which released her 1992 debut album, Whatâ€™s The 411? Harrell coined the nickname Queen of Hip-Hop Soul to describe the fresh way Bligeâ€™s music melded rap beats with R&B hooks.â€
With a career spanning over three decades, Mary J Blige has seen hip-hop evolve firsthand, from the golden era of Tupac Shakur and Biggie Smalls to the rise of todayâ€™s chart-dominating â€œmumble rapâ€ sound. As the undisputed Queen of Hip-Hop Soul, the New York City native has been around long enough to witness the greats at their peak, making her well-equipped to weigh in on who stands tall in the game today.
Speaking to Manny Norte onCapital XTRA, Blige didnâ€™t hesitate when asked which rappers sheâ€™s feeling right now. â€œIâ€™m feeling Kendrick Lamar. Iâ€™m feeling Drake. Theyâ€™re at the top of the list as far as rappers who should really be respected from the new generationâ€¦ Theyâ€™re killing it,â€ she declared.
Bligeâ€™s praise for both artists came long before their ongoing lyrical warfare erupted, but itâ€™s unlikely either of them took much noticeâ€”or cared. With their public back-and-forth reaching new heights in recent months, respect from a legend like Blige seems to have taken a backseat to their increasingly personal jabs.
The tension between Drake and Kendrick isnâ€™t new. The two have spent the better part of a decade subtly (and not-so-subtly) jostling for the top spot in hip-hop. Their rivalry dates back to the early 2010s, when they collaborated on tracks like â€˜Poetic Justiceâ€™ before veering into competition. Drake has long positioned himself as the commercial juggernaut of hip-hop, while Kendrick has solidified himself as the genreâ€™s uncompromising lyricist and critic of the mainstream.
Bligeâ€™s connection to both rappers runs deep. She worked with Kendrick onGood Kid, M.A.A.D City, appearing on the trackâ€˜Now or Neverâ€™, and stood alongside him during the 2022 Super Bowl Halftime Show. Meanwhile, her history with Drake goes back even further. The Toronto superstar not only featured on her 2009 track â€˜The Oneâ€™ but also penned her 2011 song â€˜Mr. Wrongâ€™. He later paid homage by sampling â€˜Maryâ€™s Jointâ€™ on â€˜Weston Road Flowsâ€™ fromViewsin 2016.
Did Bligeâ€™s mention of the two titans help fuel the fire that led to Kendrickâ€™s venomous verse on â€˜Like Thatâ€™? Or are they simply two heavyweight rappers destined to be admired by legends and fans alike? As a lover of hip-hopâ€™s ever-unfolding drama, Iâ€™m leaning toward the former.

title: Tommy Richman: Can the rapper ever recover?
description:
The rise and fall of Tommy Richman was a weird phenomenon, which we can attribute to the internet. Like many modernhip-hopartists, he made a name for himself on TikTok. However, as weâ€™ve witnessed with others in the scene when he had real listeners looking to see what he was about, his music career started to unravel quickly.
When Richman first came to the forefront of the culture with his viral hit â€˜Million Dollar Babyâ€™, it was hard to deny that the track was catchy. The rhymer had been making music since 2019 and even had an independent album when he arrived.
However, hip-hop culture was unsure of what he represented musically and knew little about him. Richmanâ€™s aesthetic presented him as a rapper, yet his platinum single was aDirty South singalong.Â As such, he was initially a confusing proposition. Still, the Virginia musician who was signed toBrent Faiyazâ€™s label ISO Supremacydidnâ€™t want to be a one-hit wonder with nothing to offer. As such, in interviews, such as his chat with Zane Lowe for Apple Music, he promised fans that he would showcase his true talent to the world on his albumCoyote.
During his Apple Music interview, he explained to Lowe that his entrance into the music scene wasnâ€™t what he had planned, unveiling, â€œItâ€™s really not how I imagined it. I really thought that I was gonna put out this album, and thatâ€™s how I was gonna blow up.â€
â€˜Million Dollar Babyâ€™ was everywhere during this period, and people enjoyed the sound he had introduced them to with the single. Still, while the hit track was spreading like wildfire, Richman was in the studio working onCoyoteand expecting a massive boost to his career upon its release.
In hindsight, he may have been overconfident about his ability to make a body of work as, musically, he was in no manâ€™s land. With no idea where he was going to make his mark, he releasedCoyoteto negative reviews, and the project only sold 3,400 copies in its first week. However, one incident significantly impacted the rollout of his album. In a moment of naivety, the fresh-faced artist tweeted, â€œIâ€™m not a hip-hop artist.â€ Richman did this even though he had presented himself as a rapper for his entire career and also released â€˜Million Dollar Babyâ€™, which was very successful in the world of rap music.
This angered many, as it has happened previously with white artists.Post Malone entered the music industry as a rapper and switched to country music.The same can be said for Machine Gun Kelly, who entered the business as an emcee but decided to pursue rock after using rap for his fans. Still, in the case of Tommy Richman, many people saw it as a highly ungrateful thing to do since it was hip-hop and R&B radio stations that were promoting his music.
Despite all of this, Tommy Richmanâ€™s situation is not unique nor unfamiliar to many who understand the basic principles of the music industry. Richmanâ€™s music was validated and promoted by TikTok, an app that utilizes short music clips. As such, it is unsurprising when acts such as Richman and Ice Spice come to the fore and reveal that beyond catchy 30-second snippets, their musical capability is low.
Although technology may have advanced since the 1990s, unfortunately for people such as Tommy Richman, the basic tenets of the music industry havenâ€™t. Only real musicians who build fanbases from the ground up achieve longevity in the industry, and whether itâ€™s Ice Spice, the Island Boys, or Bhad Babie, success derived from social media is short-lived, and once the hype has died down, it will be hard to recover from the fall.

title: How Drake made J Cole change his sound out of fear
description:
J Colewas partially disgraced last year after getting roped into Drake and Kendrick Lamarâ€™s feud. The battle between Drake and Kendrick Lamar escalated quickly. However, due to his initialinvolvement in â€˜First Person Shooterâ€™,J Cole released his diss track entitled â€˜7 Minute Drillâ€™.
However, during a performance at his annual festival, the Dreamiville Fest in Raleighâ€™s Dorothea Dix Park on April 7th, the â€˜Wet Dreamzâ€™ emcee told fans he was proud ofhis 2024 project,Might Delete Laterbut was ashamed of the song â€˜7 Minute Drillâ€™ and even apologised to Kendrick for it.
While taking a break onstage, Cole explained to the crowd his feelings aboutMight Delete Later, stating, â€œIâ€™m so proud of that project except for one part [but] thereâ€™s one part of that sh*t that makes me feel like, â€˜Man, thatâ€™s the lamest sh*t I ever did in my f*cking life.'â€
Despite last yearâ€™s drama and craziness, before he even became famous, J Cole was aware of Drake. He stated that the Toronto native made him change his sound. In fact, Cole insinuated that before he heard Drake, he was planning on entering the industry by fusing R&B with hip-hop and wasnâ€™t interested in anything conscious. During an episode ofInevitable,Cole recalled hearing Drizzy for the first time online, reflecting, â€œIt was one dude in particular that I remember seeing on MySpace, and he was this light-skinned R&B-looking n*gga, but he had raps.â€
While speaking with Dreamvilee co-founder Ibrahim Hamad, Cole admitted that he loved Drakeâ€™s style but didnâ€™t understand why he was so popular on MySpace, stating, â€œIt was kind of neo-soul-type raps, like on some Little Brother sh*t, but he was talking about women or something. The n*ggaâ€™s whole demeanour was hella smooth. He continued, â€œHis plays were through the roof for a n*gga youâ€™ve never heard of or has never been signed! I was like, â€˜Who is this n*gga?! How does he have 20,000 plays in a day?!â€
Although J Cole liked Drakeâ€™s music, he felt that theViewscreator was stepping on his toes, explaining,  â€œFor so long, I felt confident in the fact that I was the only one occupying that space, the only one with that perspective and that sharp of a pen!â€
He added, â€œI was like, â€˜Thatâ€™s gonna be my thing, thatâ€™s whatâ€™s gonna separate me from the pack. So the second I heard [â€˜Say Whatâ€™s Realâ€™], one, I was blown away because of how good it was. But two, subconsciously, I was like, â€˜Ha! There was someone else out there the whole time that was working maybe just as hard as I was working, was thinking the same things, and who had the same opportunity to occupy a certain lane that I never saw any competition for.'â€
â€œMy deal with Jay ainâ€™t even done. Iâ€™m not even anybody yet. And this n*ggaâ€™s off to the races with hits, like cultural-shifting sh*t.â€™ At that moment, I had to shift my mindset about whatThe Warm Upwas about to be â€™cause Drake just changed the game.â€

title: The legendary beat 2Pac battled to get: â€œSlow, thuggish shitâ€
description:
2Pacrapped in various styles, and it is fair to say that he was a versatile artist. From hardcore, aggressive gangsta rap beats and G-funk to slow, mellow backing tracks, theAll Eyez On Mecreator could bring soul and aggression to a song. That said, there was one simple yet legendary beat he wanted to use that caused a rupture between him and his crew, The Outlawz.
For his Makaveli album, the emcee wanted something a bit slower but still sinister. He tasked producer Hurt-M-Badd with producing it, and in less than an hour, he came up with what is now a classicâ€” â€˜Hail Maryâ€™.
During an interview, Outlawz member E.D.I recalled Shakur asking Hurt-M-Badd for a beat, remembering, â€œPac told him, â€˜I need some slow, thuggish shit.'â€ Still, the result was polarising. During a discussion withXXL,the beatmaker detailed how much the late legend loved the instrumental, recalling, â€œWhen I heard it, I didnâ€™t think it was a hit. I was like, â€˜Why is Tupac laying this stuff down over my track?'â€
But 2Pac was a visionary. During a listening party, when everybody doubted the track and its entire vibe, the lyricist apparently â€œthrew his hand up in the air with his Hennessy bottle [and] threw his hand up in the air like he ruled a nation.â€
Despite 2Pacâ€™s love for the â€œslowâ€ and â€œthuggishâ€ instrumental that Hurt-M-Badd, his entourage of MCs (The Outlawz) had a deep hate for the song and initially didnâ€™t even want to rap on it.
While speaking to DJ Vlad, EDI explained, â€œI didnâ€™t like the beat because it was more of a church beat, and, being from New York, we were used to that boom-bap head-knocking beat.â€ However, he admitted that once the audio engineer added some magic, it came to life, and confessed, â€œThat changed when I heard the mix, though.â€
EDI vividly detailed the recording process of â€˜Hail Maryâ€™ and told DJ Vlad, â€œWe just did the song in an hour and a half. It wasnâ€™t my favourite record on Makaveli. It reminded me of some down-South record. I didnâ€™t know it was going to be as big a record as it is today.â€
The track has become a fan favourite, and although it wasnâ€™t hugely popular when it was first released, it has become legendary over the years. Its introspective, spiritual nature saw a different side to 2Pac, who was known for his passionate, aggressive delivery.
â€˜Hail Maryâ€™was slower than a regular 2Pac beat and more gospel-inspiredthan anything he had previously released. Its understated bass, soft electric piano, and simple drum loop made it seem rather unremarkable. The song didnâ€™t make waves commercially until it was re-released in 1998 as part ofthe legendary posthumousGreatest Hitsalbumas it captured the emotional nature of the late emcee and reflected the broader sentiment surrounding his death, which was one of sadness yet full of hope.
The lyrics and, more specifically, the chorus of â€˜Hail Maryâ€™ have gone on to take a line of their own, with the singing melody of 2Pac on the track being instantly recognisable to any fan of hip-hop.

AndrÃ© 3000 does genius work. Bono, absolutely. Chris Martinâ€™s a genius. Dr Dre, genius. Rick Rubin, super genius.â€

title: The unique LA collective that Ice Cube once compared to The Pharcyde
description:
Ice Cubeis a legend and was one of the earliest MCs to take over the West Coast. Still, over the years, he has proven to be more than just a rapper. The â€˜You Can Do Itâ€™ rhymer has appeared in movies on television and has co-created and directed documentaries.
In 2020, the Crenshaw native became part of the West Coast supergroup Mount Westmore alongside old-school legends such as E-40, Too $hort and Snoop Dogg. However,although he is an emcee from the 1980s, the lyricist has always kept an eye on the current music scene in California. Odd Future particularly piqued Ice Cubeâ€™s interest, and he showed a lot of admiration for their extraordinary come up.
Odd Future were a phenomenon when they first surfaced in the early 2010s. Formed in LA, the kooky collective exploded into the mainstream in 2011. The crewâ€™s distinct look came with a previously unheard sound that took the culture by storm.
Odd Future were pioneering in the way they effortlessly fused LA Skate culture with hip-hop and managed to created a cult following. Hip-hop and skate culture are entirely separate entities that would have seemed incompatible before. However, Odd Future seamlessly married them.

title: The strange way Soulja Boy got his stage name
description:
Since his breakout single â€˜Crank That,â€™Soulja Boyhas become one of the most despised MCs in hip-hop. The Atlanta artist is known as a brash, arrogant and flashy character whose material does not match his ego. However, the emcee did have an undeniable impact on rap music.

Produced by Soulja Boy, â€˜Crank Thatâ€™ with its famous â€œSupermanâ€ line, birthed a new hip-hop style reminiscent of Crunk, where the song had multiple calls to action that engaged audiences significantly.
Soulja Boy was a product of the MySpace era and early YouTube age when songs such as â€˜Chicken Noodle Soupâ€™ by Young B and â€˜Donkâ€™ ran rampant around the internet. They appealed to a highly young demographic that wanted to have fun and learn dance moves instead of hearing gangsta rap.
In the 2000s, Soulja Boy was a big deal, and people were interested in his backstory. During a television interview with Bill Werde ofBillboard,the emcee spoke about the origins of his name and the kind of music he made before fame.
When asked how he chose the name Soulja Boy, the â€˜Turn My Swag Onâ€™ rhymer unveiled, â€œI got that name from my momma! My momma gave me that name when I was real little whenI was staying in Atlantaon Simpson Road, westside, and I just kept it with me.â€
The lyricist continued, â€œWhen I started rappinâ€™, I used â€˜Dre,â€™ and after that, I changed it to Soulja Boy.â€ The rapper then told a story about a song he made under the moniker, telling Werde, â€œItâ€™s funny â€™cause the first song I made [as] Soulja Boy, it was called â€˜Ready For Warâ€™,Â  my momma actually gave me the beat for it!â€
According to the emcee his mother knew a producer in the city who gave him that beat. However, when he first broke onto the scene he didnâ€™t make use of those contacts as â€˜Crank Datâ€™ was made by him on production software Fruity Loops.
In an interview, he explained, â€œTo be honest, it took me an hour to produce the â€˜Crank Thatâ€™ song â€“ at the most.â€ He continued, â€œSometimes I just sit backâ€¦ I can make a beat in my hotel room, or I can make a beat in my dressing room while getting ready for a show, and I can send it to Pro Tools, and bam, get it right back recorded on my laptop. Then I can post it for all my fans to hear.â€
Although Soulja Boy is a household name, he is most definitely an artist who is associated with the past and a bygone era. title: The moment Jay-Z left the streets behind: â€œThis life has no good endingâ€
description:
Before becoming a billionaire and one of the greatest rappers of all time,Jay-Zsold drugs around the Marcy Projects. He started selling drugs at the age of 13 after the crack epidemic took hold in the 1980s. After his father left when he was 11, Jay found his place in the streets, looking up to dealers in his local neighbourhood.
However, after experiencing multiple deaths and incarcerations, Hov realised he needed to find a way out. â€œI started seeing people go to jail and get killed, and the light slowly came on,â€ he told Oprah Winfrey. â€œI was like, â€˜This life has no good ending.'â€
Jay was in his early adulthood when he came to this realisation. He split his time between drug dealing and rapping,becoming known as Jazzy, selling records out of his car. Hova gained a loyal following before launching his label, Roc-A-Fella Records, in 1996.
He was around 20 years old when he decided that he needed to quit the streets to pursue a thriving music career. â€œIâ€™d been trying to transition from the streets to the music business, but I would make demos and then quit for six months,â€ he said toO Magazine. â€œAnd I started to realise that I couldnâ€™t be successful until I let the street life go.â€
Jay took advice from his mother in putting an end to selling drugs, believing he had to put his all into making a career out of music. It was a considerable risk but one worth taking.
â€œMy mom always taught meâ€”you know, little boys listen to their mums too muchâ€”that whatever you put into something is what youâ€™re going to get out of it,â€ he recalled. â€œI had to fully let go of what I was doing before for the music to be successful. That was a leap of faith for me. I said, â€˜I have to give this everything.'â€
Everything Jay experienced up until age 26 was put into his debut album,Reasonable Doubt, which was released in June 1996. Itâ€™s his favourite project of his career because it presented his life struggles until that point, allowing him to pour his heart and soul into it when he wasnâ€™t the success story he is today.
â€œThat first album,Reasonable Doubt,is my favourite because all the emotions and experiences of 26 years came out in it,â€ he said. â€œThat was the record I had 26 years to make.â€
Hov sold drugs as a way to survive in Brooklyn and learned how to manage money along the way. â€œI know about budgets. I was a drug dealer,â€ he toldVanity Fair. â€œTo be in a drug deal, you need to know what you can spend, what you need to re-up.â€
When asked if he regrets dealing drugs, he said, â€œNot until later, when I realised the effects on the community. I started looking at the community on the whole, but in the beginning, no. I was thinking about surviving. I was thinking about improving my situation. I was thinking about buying clothes.â€

They combined for albums such asSupa Dupa Fly,Da Real World,Miss Eâ€¦ So Addictive,Under Construction andThis Is Not a Test!, resulting in hit singles like â€˜Work Itâ€™, â€˜Get Ur Freak Onâ€™, â€˜Hot Boyzâ€™ and â€˜The Rain (Supa Dupa Fly)â€™.
The rapper-producer duo are both from Virginia Beach and met through Timbalandâ€™s longtime collaborator, Magoo,with whom he released three albums. Through a mutual friend, Magoo met Tim, who was more of a DJ than a producer at that point.
â€œI first met Tim through a guy who is Tim and Iâ€™s best friend,â€ he toldRed Bull Music Academy.â€œHis name is Larry Lyons. I met Larry when he came to Chesapeake, Virginia to attend high school. He was from Virginia Beach. Within a month, he started telling me about this guy in Virginia Beach who was a really good DJ, beat boxer, and producer. But at the time, Tim was more well-known for being a DJ.â€
Magoo then introduced Timbaland to Missy Elliott afterdiscovering her group, Fayze(later known as Sista), through another friend. He told the collective about Tim, and they were sold the first time they met him.
â€œI met Tim in 1988 when he was 16 years-old,â€ he explained. â€œI met Missy through someone else, too. Initially, Larry, Tim, and I were in a record store. Missy was in a group called Fayze, and they had a record out locally, and it was playing on the radio already. The song was performing pretty well. While I was in the record store, I picked up their record. I was like, â€˜We have to meet these girls.â€™
â€œAbout a month later, a guy from my neighbourhood calls me and said, â€˜I have Fayze in the car with me.â€™ So, I get in the car with them, and I started telling them about Tim. We ended up going over to Virginia Beach, and when we got there, they met Tim.â€
He continued, â€œWhen they met him, they wanted to pick him up as a producer. Unfortunately for the guy who introduced me to them, he was also a producer, but they ended up choosing Tim to work with. This was around 1991 or 1992.â€
Sista released one album,4 All the Sistas Around da World, in 1994. Timbaland produced Missy Elliottâ€™s solo debut,Supa Dupa Fly, three years later. Speaking on the album on X (formerly Twitter) in 2022, she said, â€œMy first album was stress-free because I didnâ€™t have any expectations. My label told me they would give me my own label if I did one album so me and Timbaland completed this album in two weeks, not knowing this would be the beginning of many more to come.â€
As for the follow-up,Da Real World, released in 1999, she admitted, â€œI was so hard on myself and for a while, this was my least favourite, until years later I realised the MASTERPIECE Timbaland and I had created.â€

title: Black Thoughtâ€™s favourite rap verse of all time: â€œIt gave me hopeâ€
description:
Black Thoughtis a master of his craft and considered one of the best MCs of all time for good reason. As the lead vocalist of The Roots, heâ€™s released classic albums like 1995â€™sDo You Want More?!!!??!, 1996â€™sIlladelph Halflifeand 1999â€™sThings Fall Apart. Fast-forward to today, heâ€™s branched out with equally impressive projects alongside Danger Mouse, Salaam Remi and 9th Wonder.
The 51-year-old (real name Tariq Trotter) wouldnâ€™t have developed the skills on display today without some of his inspirations.He cites Rakim, Big Daddy Kane, and WhodiniÂ as early influences while also nodding to George Clinton, Stevie Wonder, and Sly and the Family Stone.
However, his favourite rap verse of all time belongs to Kool G Rap. The New York City rapper is one of the most gifted lyricists ever to do it, inspiring future greats such as Biggie Smalls, Nas, Eminem and Jay-Z. Thoughtâ€™s ultimate G Rap verse appears on â€˜Road to the Richesâ€™ from his 1989 album with DJ Polo.
â€œKool G Rap has always been super scalpel sharp,â€ he toldPitchfork. â€œIt was, you know, it was repetitive in that way, but in a good way. In a way, that was inspiring to me. That sort of rubbed off, whether it was what I was trying to do or not, you know what I mean? It just, thatâ€™s what was impressive for me.â€
Thought went into detail about the first time he heard the song as a school kid, having just formed a partnership with Questlove. Little did he know then that it was the origins of The Roots.
â€œThe first time I heard â€˜Road to the Richesâ€™ I was probably somewhere ninth or 10th grade,â€ he explained. â€œI recently formed a rap group with my partner, who was a drummer at the time, who would later go on tocall himself Questlove, and I would later call myself Black Thought. We would later become The Roots but we were, I donâ€™t know what we were called at that time.
â€œI was also working after school I had an after school job at a pizza place called Pizzeria Uno. And I remember I had like a yellow sort of sports Walkman that was chunky and you could drop it without breaking it and stuff. I would listen to this record on my way to work and on my way home at three oâ€™clock in the morning after work.â€
Black Thought could relate to the lyrics due to his job at the time, giving him inspiration as a young man trying to make it in life. â€œI just really identified with the story of not only was it arags to riches story, with which I could absolutely identify because I was in the rags phase of my life,â€ he said. â€œBut he was talking about in this tale, which is a well-rounded sort of narrative and a full cautionary tale.
â€œHe was talking about working in a restaurant, and being a porter. And washing dishes and sweeping floors and doing many of the things that I was doing while listening to this record. So, it sort of gave me hope. You know what I mean? It gave me hope as an artist that where I was in life, I wasnâ€™t necessarily destined to be there forever.â€

title: The bizarre story of hip-hopâ€™s fascination with Grey Poupon
description:
Rappers (as street poets) use a lot of brand names in their rhymes, and, in contemporary hip-hop, theyâ€™re usually confined to luxury alcohol brands and designer clothes. However, there is an outlier which seems to appear again and again in hip-hop without fail.
The brand name that seems to have found a home in rap lyrics is Grey Poupon, the mustard brand. Itâ€™s not because MCs have a particular affinity for mustard or even because it is particularly high-end, but its persistence is strange.
From Ghostface Killah and Kanye to Raekwon and Lil Wayne, across eras from the 1980s to the present, lyricists have referenced the condiment brand, and not for no reason. It comes as no surprise thatbrand names such as Rolex, Gucci, and Ferrarimake regular appearances. Still, Grey Poupon? Does it have any particular allure?
Well, fans can trace the story back to the 1980s when the mustard brand launched an expensive and unrelenting commercial campaign that led to Americans knowing the phrase  â€œPardon me, do you have any Grey Poupon?â€ by heart. The Dijon mustard brand began by advertising in newspapers read by older middle-class generations. Still, after presenting the condiment as a luxury but affordable in a series of television advertisements, Grey Poupon saw a 100% jump in sales.
The first commercial from 1981 spiked sales, and the second round saw a similar rise. The television advertisements presented the mustard brand in a range of settings, including on yachts, at fancy parties, and in luxury cars, which gave the brand a reputation for being fancy. The television advertising campaign crafted by Lee Garfinkel ran in various forms until 1991 when the first Grey Poupon reference appeared in hip-hop.
In 1991, Das EFX began recording their debut studio album,Dead Serious, which went platinum after its release. However, on the track â€˜East Coastâ€™ we see the first mention of the condiment when he rhymes â€œHeâ€™s the don, have you seen my Grey Poupon? Bust this, we roll more spliffs than Cheech and Chong.â€
Still, since then, the use of the brand name has risen and risen even though it is no longer seen as culturally relevant. During an interview, Open Mike Eagle explained why he believes it appears so often, stating, â€œI think for this particular phrase, there are a couple of reasons for it. First of all, it is just how convenient of a rhyme it is. It rhymes with coupon, neutron, futon and all of these things that are around.â€
However, one of the main reasons it has stuck around is its original advert and its association with being of a high class. The mustard was only ever seen being used by upper-class individuals and was always presented as a must-have for wealthy people looking for â€œgourmetâ€ mustard. As such, it has becomea strange status symbol akin to Cristal and Hennessy.
Although rappers were still mentioning it in the early 2000s, the sheer number of number-one hit tracks that mentioned the brand name in 2007 led to a massive jump in people using the mustard for their rhymes. From Kendrick Lamar to Lil Wayne and Kanye West, it saw such a rise that West was still using it in 22016 onLife Of Pablo,rapping, â€œYeezy, Yeezy, Yeezy, this is pure luxury / I give â€™em Grey Poupon on a DJ Mustard, ah!â€
Hip-hopâ€™s obsession with Grey Poupon most definitely shows that, with clever marketing and an emphasis on luxury, you can most definitely make a brand the next rap music brand buzzword.

title: The moment Ice Cube knew he had to leave NWA: â€œI refused to take my chequeâ€
description:
NWAâ€™s beef withIce Cubehas become one of hip-hopâ€™s most notorious feuds because it culminated in one of hip-hopâ€™s most savage diss tracks â€” â€˜No Vaselineâ€™. The song effectively led to the collectiveâ€™s destruction and still stands as one of the best diss tracks ever made.
NWA was a legendary group, and the gangsta rap movement it sparked was epic. However, despite being a proud member of the collective, Ice Cube had a tenuous relationship with his fellow members. Alongside Dr Dre, Eazy-E, DJ Yella, and MC Ren, Cube reached the top of the charts in the 1980s, but one individual drove a wedge between theDeath Certificatecreator and the rest of his group â€”Jerry Heller.
The group, which was formed in 1986, had massive commercial success. Still, Ice Cube decided to break away from the collective after becoming frustrated with Jerry Heller, the crewâ€™s manager and founder of Ruthless Records.
Eazy-E put much of his faith in Heller, but Ice Cube knew the collective was getting ripped off by the executive and not being given what they were worth. In his diss track, the emcee aimed at all of his former friends and highlighted their blind loyalty. Furthermore, he believed that Eazy-E (as the groupâ€™s frontman) was taking a more significant cut than he deserved for songs they had all contributed to.
During an interview withNME,Ice Cube explained the exact turning point in his career that led him to leave NWA. Speaking about the unfair paymenthe received forStraight Outta Comptonand the dodgy cheque he was pressured to take from Heller, theLethal Injectioncreator recalled, â€œI refused to take my cheque because I felt that I would be admitting that I agreed with what I was beinâ€™ paid.â€
However, the sum of money he was turning down seemed like a lot to his peers. Speaking about how his counterparts were aghast at his decision not to take the money from Jerry Heller, the emcee continued, â€œThey [the other group members] thought I was crazy! I heard comments like, â€˜For $75,000, I donâ€™t care what that contract says. I would sign that shit two times.â€™ They were like, â€˜Whatâ€™s wrong with you? This is more money than weâ€™ve ever seen, and you wanna be the dark cloud in the shit?'â€
Still, it wasnâ€™t justStraight Outta Comptonthat Ice Cube was unhappy with; he also believed that he had contributed much to Eazy-Eâ€™s debut project,Eazy-Duz-It.Unfortunately for him, Eazy-E wasnâ€™t looking to give any money for his work.
Opening up about the release ofEazy-Duz-Itshortly after the groupâ€™s debut, Ice Cube toldNME,â€œThe cheque was just forStraight Outta Compton,but weâ€™d worked on both records equally! I felt like we deserved more of both pies. We put as much time and effort intoEazy-Duz-Itas intoStraight Outta Comptonâ€“ all of us. But Eazy wanted to keep all theEazy-Duz-Itmoney and just pay us the NWA money and take his share out of the NWA money!â€
In the long term, Ice Cube knew it wouldnâ€™t be sustainable to have one NWA member getting paid more than the rest regularly without some sort of unrest, so he decided toput his feelings on â€˜No Vaselineâ€™ and leave.That said, his decision wasnâ€™t that controversial because the year his diss track was released, Dr Dre also left the collective to form Death Row Records, meaning evenThe Chroniccreator knew the NWA movement had reached an end.
After leaving NWA, Ice Cube was very successful as a solo artist and even entered Hollywood. However, he was the first to see that NWA was no longer able to survive as a group.

title: What is Busta Rhymes most challenging rap?
description:
Busta Rhymesis definitely a lyricist who is on a different level regarding lyrics. Only some MCs can rap fast, and, akin to a rapper like Eminem, Busta can pack a lot of syllables and words into his verses. Furthermore,the Brooklyn lyricisthas proven that he can add more character to his songs than many run-of-the-mill rappers.
With quirky voices, nods to his Jamaican heritage, and a clever bending of words, Busta has a way with words. However, he is most known for his quick-fire delivery; on some tracks, it is impossible to keep up with his words. Furthermore, it is often unbelievable how much he manages to say in such a short time.
Althoughthe â€˜Touch Itâ€™ can rapperquickly and often manages to do it seamlessly, he can also flow perfectly on a slow beat as evidenced on his song â€˜Pass The Courvoisier Pt IIâ€™ and â€˜Whatâ€™s It Gonna Beâ€™ featuring Janet Jackson.
Although Busta Rhymes is still making music, one of the things he is most renowned for is his impossible verses â€” the verses that are almost impossible to memorise and recite word for word perfectly. Some have tried and many have failed but we have compiled a list of some of Bustaâ€™s hardest tongue-twisters.
This 2010 track sees an appearance from the old school legend Jaz-O who mentored and helped a young Jay-Z as well as Layzie Bone and Twista who is known for his fast rhyming. However, no one can beat Busta at his own game on this track.
The instrumental, produced by DJ Kay Slay was designed to be rhymed on in double-time so every artist on the song raps speedily. Still, Busta (who appears first) manages to top the rest with his slick and effortless ability to rap at that speed with perfect breath-control.
This rock-rap track features a line-up of only lyricists and is a track thatâ€™s all about the syllables. One can literally hear the staccato syllables firing like bullets over the metal-inspired beat and incredible to behold.
Alongside Tech N9ne and MCs such as Yelawolf and Twista, Busta doesnâ€™t sound like heâ€™s rapping so fast because the track overall is so speedy itâ€™s very hard to know who is rapping when but it is indisputably a rapid-fire song.
Produced by Dr. Dre and Scott Storch, this beat is renowned, and Bustaâ€™s speed on the track is also part of the songâ€™s iconic status. Although he cleverly and intricately weaves some breaks into his verses, for the most part, it is nonstop lyrical activity from Busta on this track that is hard to comprehend.
As he hurls verse after verse at listeners, initially, it appears he has no intent on stopping. That said, he shows an unrelenting passion and as usual he is going at a pace that no other rapper could ever manage. The song was produced at 83 Beats Per Minute (BPM) but Busta Rhymes emcees in double-time choosing to deliver his lyrics at a rate of 166 bpm.
â€˜Gimme Some Moreâ€™ has an odd skip to its drum pattern, and itâ€™s something that is loved by fans but wasnâ€™t initially popular with the Brooklyn emcee. With a sample  Â of Alfred Hitchcockâ€™s 1960 cult classicPsycho, the beat is most definitely unique.
Furthermore, the producer, DJ Scratch, made it at 137 beats per minute nearly double some of hip-hopâ€™s most famous boom-bap instrumentals. Still, theGenesiscreator manages to smoothly ride the music and with a Hype Williams music video, the song has become an iconic piece of rap art.
Regardless of its status the songâ€™s second verse is unbelievably hard to follow and with several switches of flow it would be almost almost impossible to remember and recite perfectly.
This beat is iconic but Busta Rhymes verse is unbelievably hard to keep up with. in fact it is probably one of the fastest verses ever delivered in rap music. Delivered at 146 Beats Per Minute its a challenge for listeners let alone the emcee who delivered it.
Busta has become synonymous with this song and his verse is, arguably, the highlight of the track due to its energetic, dynamic and powerful delivery. The rapper has rapped it on the radio, in front of cameras and every time has done it with perfection. It is undoubtedly his fastest verse of all time.

title: Why doesnâ€™t Jay-Z write down his lyrics?
description:
Itâ€™s common knowledge thatJay-Zdoesnâ€™t write down his lyrics. The Brooklyn rapper has become one of the greatest lyricists of all time without putting pen to paper, using his memory to put words, lines and entire songs together, not to mention coming up with quadruple entendres.
That process began as a teenager when he was on the streets as a drug dealer. He didnâ€™t carry any paper notebooks around, so he had no choice but to keep his rhymes in his head. â€œThe more I got into the street, when I was 18 or 19, the furÂ­ther away from the notebook I became,â€ he explained toRolling Stone. â€œWhen I was outside, Iâ€™d start thinking of all these lyrics, and Iâ€™d find anything I could write on.
â€œSo I had all these pieces of paper in my pocket, then Iâ€™d get back to the house and dump all these papers out and put â€™em in the notebook. You can only have so many pieces of paper in your pockets, so I started memorising some lines until I got back to the book. It was like an exercise. Pretty soon I would just memorise all these songs, and it grew from there. When I made my first demos, around â€™92, that was my process.â€
However, that same process has also led to Jay-Z losing many ideas. â€œIâ€™ve lost a lot of songs that way,â€ he toldCBS News. â€œIâ€™ve lost a lot of material. But it just came with life.â€
The only time he ever wrote down lyrics was for â€˜Can I Liveâ€™ from his debut albumReasonable Doubtin 1996. â€œWhat happened was, I was doing that song with someone else, and they heard the first verse and they was like, â€˜Man, you take that song. Finish it, â€™cause it sounds like you got a lot more to say,â€™â€ he said toMTV News. â€œSo I just wanted to get it down quick, I didnâ€™t want to keep going over it. It was like [the album] mastering time, so I just sat down in the booth and wrote that [verse].â€
Jay-Z attempted to write down all of his lyrics for 2003â€™sThe Black Album, which was intended to be his final album before retirement, but he couldnâ€™t shake off the format he knows best. â€œIt just felt better [the way I do it now],â€ heÂ said. â€œIn my mind, I said, â€˜OK, Iâ€™m gonna sit down and Iâ€™mma just write it and really do this thing a certain way.â€™ But your natural process is your process. Itâ€™s difficult to go back to what you was doing when you was 15, 16 years old. My process is different now.â€
He added, â€œIt sounds great on paper, like â€˜Iâ€™mma sit down, Iâ€™m going to write the entire album like I did before.â€™ But once you get back in the studio and youâ€™ve been doing this process for years and years now, so it just felt natural to do it the way Iâ€™ve been doing it: no paper, no pen, just listen to the music.â€

However, that eagerness to impress Dre was also why he initially hated â€˜My Name Isâ€™. During an interview withRolling Stone, Slim Shady spoke about disliking the song because of its commercial aspect when it was released.

He added, â€œI probably felt, â€˜Iâ€™m just rapping on there!â€™ Iâ€™m just going, â€˜Hi, my name is â€” my name is â€” my name is â€”Â chka-chka,Â Slim Shady.â€™ Thatâ€™s it. It was an introduction to the world, but I didnâ€™t know it was an introduction to the world.â€
To this day, â€˜My Name Isâ€˜ remains one of the biggest songs of Emâ€™s career. It has gone four times platinum in the US and two times platinum in the UK. The track boasts over 694 million Spotify streams, and its music video has also racked up 278 million views on YouTube.
Eminem takes pride in his lyrics and isnâ€™t content with his delivery until heâ€™s pushed himself to the fullest. â€œIf I feel Iâ€™ve pushed myself to the furthest extent that I can, then itâ€™s done. title: The rapper who wrote for Kanye West without credit: â€œThere are a lot of songsâ€
description:

title: How The Game ruined his own career
description:

By judging The Game on his antics over the past few years, you could be forgiven for forgetting just how pivotal he was for West Coast rap in the post-Death Row era.
Still, back in 2005, The Game nearly single-handedly resurrected the coast. With a five-times platinum, critically acclaimed album,The Documentary,the emcee undoubtedly produced one of the best hip-hop projects of the 2000s.

Still, byreleasingThe Doctorâ€™s Advocateonly one year after his debut, he game did the near impossible by proving to the world he could still deliver a stellar album without Dreâ€™s guiding hand or 50 Cent giving him a whole host of hooks.

However, as the years went on, The Game showed his unprofessionalism on social media and in interviews where he couldnâ€™t resist talking about Dre and Jimmy Iovine. But as fast as lie doing a beat forThe Documentary.No. Iâ€™ve never had a Dre beat in my career. title: Explaining Missy Elliottâ€™s backwards â€˜Work Itâ€™ verse
description:
Missy Elliottis one of hip hopâ€™s most cherished female MCs. Rising to prominence by the side of Timbaland in the mid-1990s, the rapper is loved for her funny lyrics, provocative raps and outlandish music videos that leave her listeners mindblown. Known as one of hip hopâ€™s first mainstream female MCs, Missy is definitely one of the greats.
However, her career would not begin properly until herÂ partnership with Timbaland. The two made music by working behind the scenes, writing and producing for Râ€™nâ€™B acts, such as Aaliyah, SWV, and Total. In 1997, Elliott released herdebut album,Supa Dupa Fly,and her career skyrocketed.
Elliottâ€™s first album would spawn her first top 20 hit, â€˜Sock It 2 Meâ€™. The album landed at number three on the Billboard 200, becoming the highest-charting debut LP for a female rapper. Continuing to work alongside her good friend Timbaland, Elliot would release her second record,Da Real World, in 1999, and by 2000, the album was quickly certified platinum by the RIAA.
In less than a decade, Missy Elliott became one of the greats of hip-hop and was integral in legitimising female rap alongside the likes of Queen Latifah and Lilâ€™ Kim. That said, she released some seminal tracks at the turn of the millennium. From â€˜Supa Dupa Flyâ€™ to â€˜Iâ€™m Really Hotâ€™, it is indisputable that she has put out a lot of music.
Still, one of her biggest anthems was â€˜Work Itâ€™. Releasedas a single for her 2002 albumUnder Construction,it debuted at number two on the Billboard Hot 100 and became three times platinum. The beat (produced by Timbaland) sampled Run-DMCâ€™s â€˜Peter Piperâ€™ and Rock Master Scott & the Dynamic Threeâ€™s â€˜Request Lineâ€™.
Still, one part of the track became iconic: the reverse vocal in the chorus section. For years, people didnâ€™t know what the Virginia native was saying, and many believed she might have been saying something explicit, as parts of the track are quite cheeky. However, that couldnâ€™t be further from the truth.
In fact, the addition of the reverse vocal was a complete accident. During an interview, Missy Elliott revealed that the quirky element resulted from an accident by the audio engineer she was working with. Opening up to theAssociated Press,Elliott explained how it materialised, beginning, â€œThe reverse thing, that was a mistake.â€
She continued, â€œThe engineer happened to hit something, and it just went backwards, and I was like, â€˜Oh, thatâ€™s kind of crazyâ€™ because it went backwards on the beat. So after that happened, I said, â€˜Yo, keep that in there, and Iâ€™m going to write around it.â€
Missy Elliott was surprised at peopleâ€™s assumptions about what she was potentially saying and revealed, â€œThey thought I was saying all kinds of nasty stuff,â€ Elliott said. â€œNo, actually, Iâ€™m not this time.â€
The actual phrase that Missy Elliott rapped in her reverse section is identical to the line that precedes it: â€œPut my thing down flip it, and reverse it.â€ As such, itâ€™s supposedly meant to come out as Ti esrever dna ti pilf, nwod gniht ym tup.â€
Although it was not dirty, for some years, fans were under the assumption it was Missy Elliott asking, â€œIs your p*ssy getting wet yet?â€ However, she has debunked this several times now. The reverse section is the most iconic part of â€˜Work Itâ€™. In fact, itâ€™s so recognisable that Elliott recreated a backwards section at a later part of the song.

title: The reason why Chance The Rapper quit acid: â€œIâ€™m done with thisâ€
description:
Chance The Rappermade his breakthrough in 2013 withAcid Rap. The mixtape was inspired by and even named after acid, but shortly after the project came out, he was done with taking the psychedelic drug.
With the tape, the Chicago rapper took the hip-hop world by storm alongside guests such as Childish Gambino, Twista, Action Bronson, Ab-Soul, BJ The Chicago Kid, Vic Mensa, Saba, and Noname. He continued, â€œI had to deal with that and also realise that my projects described experiences that I had already been through. But they were not the sum of me or the whole exploration of who I am as a person.â€
Chance decided to quit acid following the release ofAcid Rapdue to the number of bad experiences he had with the drug. Despite going cold turkey, he couldnâ€™t fully escape it due to the success of his mixtape. People would offer him acid and ask questions about it, as much as he was trying to distance himself from that lifestyle.
â€œI stopped doing acid probably less than a month after the project came out,â€ he explained. â€œI was like, â€˜Iâ€™m done with this,â€™ aftertoo many bad tripsand just weird shit happening to me. But I had to deal with it for the next year and a half. Having everybody that met me trying to either offer me acid or ask me interview questions about acid, and having to be basically the spokesperson for drugs. But I had to come to myself and realise and remember that I was not making those songs off acid.
â€œI may have found some beats I liked off of acid, but it wasÂ meÂ making the songs. And I think that was probably the key thing that I learned from that experience. It was like, you could dress up something to be one thing and draw inspiration from one thing, but it doesnâ€™t necessarily mean that thatâ€™s the main ingredient to it.â€
Fans were attending Chanceâ€™s shows on acid and attempting to hand it to him, but he didnâ€™t want people taking it in that environment. This is coming from someone who made and broke relationships while taking the drug, even on his own, in public.
â€œMotherfuckers were giving us bags of a hundred tabs, or literal liquid acid, and we was like, â€˜Just chill. It is not that serious,'â€ he said. â€œBut I also understand it becauseAcid Raptook me a year to finish. And it was a lot of studio sessions where I was just listening to other peopleâ€™s music off acid or traveling to other places.
â€œYouâ€™re supposed to do acid either by yourself or with a group of people you trust, in a small controlled setting, and just trip and chill in that space. And I was like, shit, Iâ€™d take two or three tabs and just go downtown.â€

title: The beat Kendrick Lamar kept for six months before writing to it: â€œI didnâ€™t have the wordsâ€

Produced by Pharrell, â€˜Alrightâ€™ won â€˜Best Rap Songâ€™ and â€˜Best Rap Performanceâ€™ at the Grammy Awards in 2016 while receiving two other nominations. A track that might appear natural to Kendrick took a while to come to mind.

He added, â€œEventually, I came across it. Eventually, I found the right words. You know, it was a lot going on, and still, to this day, itâ€™s a lot going on. Kendrick explained that Pharrell and Taylor, an executive from Sony Music, knew the song would end up being something special long before he realised. â€œI didnâ€™t have any words,â€ he admitted. â€œP knew that that record was special. The inspiration for the song started withPharrellâ€™s lyricson the hook. â€œP had theâ€˜alright.â€™Â Thatâ€™s him on the hook. â€˜Alrightâ€™ has amassed over 906 million streams on Spotify, and the equally powerful music video has 187 million YouTube views. 10 years after its release, the song stands the test of time and remains a standout in Kendrickâ€™s catalogue.

title: The only reason MF DOOM became a rapper: â€œI donâ€™t listen to hip-hop musicâ€

title: â€˜Wah Gwan Delilahâ€™: The most tragic song Drake has ever recorded

Many have argued thatsince the release ofScorpionin 2018,which included hits such as â€˜Godâ€™s Planâ€™ and â€˜In My Feelingsâ€™, Drizzyâ€™s albums have worsened, with each project being more disappointing than the last. Internet users have described it as â€œcrappily producedâ€ and packed â€œwith awful fake patoisâ€ which it is but, as far as Drizzy goes, it is the most tragic song he has ever recorded to date and is arguably one of the most tragic tracks ever made by a hip-hop emcee since the genre was created.

Roddy raps on the catchy hook, â€œI justâ€…hit a lick with the box/ Hadâ€…to put the stick in the box.â€ Much of its success has been credited to the â€œeee errâ€ sound heard throughout the song, which helped it go viral across social media. While it may sound like something crafted by the producer, the sound is actually Roddy himself.
â€œAnybody who listens to music knows itâ€™s his voice,â€ producer 30 Roc toldHipHopDX. â€œThatâ€™s not possible. Itâ€™s possible for me to do that, but if I was to put that in the beat without him laying the vocals, I felt like it would throw the beat off. Iâ€™m happy that he actually did that instead of us actually adding a chant before the vocals. Itâ€™s so crazy to me. I have real producers that be asking me, â€˜Is this a part of your beat?â€™ And Iâ€™m like, â€˜Dude, you can tell this is Roddyâ€™s voice.â€™ If you really listen to it, itâ€™s definitely Roddyâ€™s voice.â€
â€˜The Boxâ€™ came to life in New York City, recorded in just 15 minutes at the end of an all-night studio session. If only he had known what would happen to his world after coming up with that idea in the early morning hours.
While Roddy has struggled to find the same success since, with songs like â€˜High Fashionâ€™ and â€˜Late at Nightâ€™ only breaking number 20 on the Hot 100, heâ€™s still certified himself as a force of the 2020s. Roc claimed he knew â€˜The Boxâ€™ would â€œchange both of our livesâ€ simply from listening to the beat, and his intuition was strong.

title: The five scariest rap verses in hip-hop history
description:
Hip-hopgives rappers the platform to spill their guts, be it threatening lyrics or candid thoughts about suicide. A combination of these things have resulted in some of the most shocking and memorable moments in music history.
Whether itâ€™s attacking other artists in the industry, venting over troubles with a significant or drunkenly opening up about dark thoughts, weâ€™ve seen it all over the years. More than ever, rappers are feeling more comfortable about laying it all on the floor.
From Ice Cube letting off steam in the 1990s to Tyler, The Creator introducing the world to his graphic lyrics, fans have been taken on whirlwind of horror throughout each decade; no matter how controversial the content might be.
With Halloween just around the corner, we take a look at five of the scariest rap verses in the history of the genre.
Tyler, The Creatorput his twisted mind on display from the get-go with the menacing â€˜Yonkersâ€™. Through violent wordplay and disses, the Odd Future leader paints a brutal picture of putting an end to pop music, complete with suicidal lyrics. The track may end with death, but the second verse targeted at Paramoreâ€™s Hayley Williams, B.o.B and Bruno Mars is one of the key reasons it was met with so much controversy.
Scariest lyric: â€œ(What you think of Hayley Williams?)/ Fuck her, Wolf Haley robbinâ€™ them/ Iâ€™ll crash that fuckinâ€™ airplane that that f-ggot n-gga B.o.B is in/ And stab Bruno Mars in his goddamn esophagus/ And wonâ€™t stop until the cops come in.â€
â€˜Kimâ€™ was the product ofEminembreaking up with Kim Mathers and being inspired by a movie he watched. Instead of writing a cheesy love song, he decided to pour out his frustration with angry lyrics about splitting amid having a daughter together. He knew it was a â€œfucked-upâ€ track but believed it showed how much he cared about her, capturing the mood of an argument between them. The final verse was the most vivid.
Scariest lyric: â€œDonâ€™t you getit, bitch? No one can hear you/ Now shut the fuck up, and get whatâ€™s cominâ€™ to you/ You were supposed to love me/ Now bleed, bitch, bleed! Bleed, bitch, bleed! Bleed!â€
The third verse of â€˜uâ€™ finds a drunkenKendrick Lamarbattling with depression. You can hear the cracks in his voice as he spits from the perspective of a guilty conscience in his head, reluctantly welcoming listeners into his mind of mood swings and the stresses of the world. So much so that he admits to crying himself to sleep at night. Itâ€™s K.Dot at his most vulnerable, resulting in one of the most impressive moments of his career to date.
Scariest lyric: â€œShouldâ€™ve killed yoâ€™ ass long time ago/ You shouldâ€™ve felt that black revolver blast a long time ago/ And if these mirrors could talk itâ€™d say, â€œYou gotta goâ€/ And if I told your secrets the worldâ€™ll know money canâ€™t stop a suicidal weakness.â€
â€˜Mind Playing Tricks on Meâ€™ is arguably the most popular Hip Hop song about paranoia. In the first verse, Scarface takes fans into his dark mind of burning bodies as a result of the gangsta lifestyle, setting the tone forGeto Boysâ€˜ Willie D and Bushwick Bill to follow suit. He doesnâ€™t hold back, admitting the paranoia heâ€™s dealing with has come to the point of holding a gun to his head at night.
Scariest lyric: â€œAt night I canâ€™t sleep, I toss and turn/ Candlesticks in the dark, visions of bodies beinâ€™ burned/ Four walls just starinâ€™ at a n-gga/ Iâ€™m paranoid, sleepinâ€™ with my finger on the trigger.â€
Dr Dreand Ice Cube combined in 1994 for â€˜Natural Born Killazâ€™, reuniting for the first time since N.W.A split up. The song was intended to appear on their scrapped joint album titledHeltah Skeltah, but ended up on 1994â€™sMurder Was the Casesoundtrack, with the lyrics resulting in their frightening best and Cube comparing himself to serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer in the third verse.
Scariest lyric: â€œHe steps in the single door/ Got his ass whipped with twenty lashes like they do up in Singapore/ So Iâ€™ma pull a fuckinâ€™ Jeffrey Dahmer/ Now heâ€™s suicidal, just like Nirvana.â€
